title: 203.4B — Exposed and Extraneous Conductive Parts
description: Learn about Exposed and Extraneous Conductive Parts in Installation 2365 Level 2
learningOutcomes: Define the terms 'exposed-conductive-part' and 'extraneous-conductive-part' according to industry standards
Identify specific examples of exposed and extraneous conductive parts within a typical installation environment
Distinguish between conductive parts that are part of the electrical system and those that are external to it

outcomes.text: Define the terms 'exposed-conductive-part' and 'extraneous-conductive-part' according to industry standards

terms.definition: A part made of material (like metal) capable of conducting electric current.
A conductive part of the electrical equipment itself (like a metal casing) which can be touched and is not normally live, but may become live under fault conditions.

A conductive part not forming part of the electrical installation (like a water pipe) but liable to introduce a potential, generally Earth potential. Industry guidance often uses a resistance to earth of less than 22,000 Ohms (22kΩ) to identify these parts.
A failure of the electrical system, such as an insulation breakdown, that causes current to flow where it shouldn't (e.g., to the metal casing).
The electric potential of the conductive mass of the Earth, conventionally taken as 0 Volts.

content.title: Exposed Conductive Parts
content.content:
### In this lesson
You will learn how to define and identify the specific components of an electrical system that are classified as exposed conductive parts.

*   Defining the term **Exposed-conductive-part**.
*   Identifying specific examples like metal casings and conduit.
*   Understanding how these parts behave during a **Fault Condition**.

**What this is**
An **Exposed-conductive-part** is a metal part of the electrical equipment that you can touch. It is not supposed to be live (energized) during normal use, but if the insulation inside fails, it can become live.

**Concrete Anchor: The Metal Toaster**
Think of a chrome toaster. Under normal operation, the metal shell is safe to touch (0 Volts). The live heating elements are inside. However, if a wire inside comes loose and touches the shell, the shell becomes energized at 230 Volts. Because the shell is part of the equipment and can be touched, it is an **Exposed-conductive-part**.

**Micro-Scenario: The Continuity Test**
How do we confirm a part is "Exposed" and properly earthed? An electrician uses a resistance tester on a metal-cased drill. They place one probe on the metal chuck and the other on the earth pin of the plug. The meter reads **0.1 Ohms** (very low resistance). This confirms the metal casing is conductive and connected to the earthing system. If it were plastic, the reading would be infinite (open circuit).

**Why it matters**
If we don't identify these parts, we might fail to earth them. Without earthing, a fault would leave the metal casing live, waiting to shock the next person who touches it.

**Key facts / rules**
*   It is part of the electrical equipment (e.g., motor frame, metal conduit, switch box).
*   It is made of conductive material (metal).
*   It is touchable (exposed).
*   It is normally safe but becomes live during a fault.

**Common mistakes**
*   **Misconception:** "Exposed" means it has no cover. **Correction:** "Exposed" means *accessible to touch*. A metal switch plate is a cover, but it is also an exposed-conductive-part.
*   **Misconception:** All metal in a room is an exposed part. **Correction:** Only metal that is *part of the electrical equipment* is an exposed part.

content.title: Check Your Understanding: Exposed Conductive Parts

questions.questionText: What is the term for a conductive part of electrical equipment which can be touched?
questions.hint: This term describes metal housings or casings that are part of the electrical equipment itself.

questions.questionText: Under what specific state can an exposed-conductive-part become live?
questions.hint: This happens when something goes wrong, such as an internal insulation failure.

questions.questionText: How is an exposed-conductive-part different from a live part regarding its intended state?
questions.hint: Live parts are meant to carry electricity to make the device work, but these parts are not.

questions.questionText: Using your answers to Q1 (touchable parts), Q2 (fault conditions), and Q3 (distinction from live parts), explain how these facts connect. Why must we identify these parts even though they are safe during normal use?
keyPoints: Exposed parts are the touchable metal surfaces of the electrical equipment itself
They are normally safe because they are not intended to be energized like live parts
They only become dangerous during a fault condition when insulation fails
We must identify them to ensure they are earthed so the supply disconnects if they become live
expectedAnswer: Exposed conductive parts are touchable metal components of equipment that are not intended to be energized like live parts are. However, because they can become live during a fault condition, we must identify them to ensure they are properly earthed for safety.

We identify these touchable parts because, unlike live parts, they are normally safe but have the potential to carry current if a fault occurs. Identifying them allows us to connect them to the earthing system to prevent electric shock.
questions.hint: Think about how the location of the part and its behavior during a failure determines why we need to earth it.

content.title: Extraneous Conductive Parts
content.content:
### In this lesson
You will learn to define **Extraneous-conductive-parts** and distinguish them from the electrical installation. These are parts that bring dangerous Earth potential into a room.

*   Defining **Extraneous-conductive-part**.
*   Distinguishing between electrical system parts and external metalwork.
*   Using resistance values to identify these parts.

**What this is**
An **Extraneous-conductive-part** is a metal part that is *not* part of the electrical wiring but can introduce a potential (usually Earth potential/0V). These are typically items like water pipes, gas pipes, or structural steel that are in contact with the ground outside.

**Concrete Anchor: The Copper Water Pipe**
Imagine a copper water pipe rising from the concrete floor. It is not connected to your fuse box, but it *is* connected to the wet soil under the building. This means the pipe is permanently at 0 Volts (Earth Potential). If you touch a live wire and this pipe at the same time, you get a shock.

**Micro-Scenario: The 22kΩ Rule**
How do we know if a piece of metal is truly "extraneous"? We measure its resistance to the ground. 
*   **Scenario A:** You measure the resistance of a metal handrail to the main earth terminal. The reading is **5,000 Ohms (5kΩ)**. This is low resistance (below the industry guideline of **22,000 Ohms**). It can easily conduct dangerous current. This **IS** an extraneous-conductive-part.
*   **Scenario B:** You measure a metal table leg standing on a dry floor. The reading is **500,000 Ohms (500kΩ)**. This is high resistance. It is isolated from the earth. This is **NOT** an extraneous-conductive-part.

**Why it matters**
If an electrical fault energizes a metal appliance casing to 230V, and you are touching a water pipe at 0V, the voltage difference across your body is 230V. To prevent this, we bond extraneous parts to the main earthing terminal, keeping everything at the same potential (Equipotential Bonding).

**Key facts / rules**
*   It is NOT part of the electrical installation.
*   It is conductive (metal).
*   It introduces a potential (usually Earth/0V).
*   **Rule of Thumb:** Resistance to earth is typically < 22kΩ.

**Common mistakes**
*   **Misconception:** Any metal object is extraneous. **Correction:** Only metal that connects to the ground (introduces potential) is extraneous. Isolated metal (like a floating metal shelf) is not.

content.title: Check Your Understanding: Extraneous Conductive Parts

questions.questionText: What is the term for a conductive part that does not form part of the electrical installation?
questions.hint: These are metal items like pipes or structural steel that are separate from the wiring system.

questions.questionText: What specific potential is an extraneous-conductive-part liable to introduce into a building?
questions.hint: This occurs because the metal part is in contact with the physical ground outside (typically 0 Volts).

questions.questionText: Why are extraneous-conductive-parts considered distinct from exposed-conductive-parts?
questions.hint: Consider whether the part contains wires and switches or if it is part of the plumbing/structure.

questions.questionText: Using your answers to Q1 (non-electrical parts), Q2 (introduced potential), and Q3 (distinction from exposed parts), explain how these facts connect. How do we know if a metal object is an extraneous-conductive-part?
keyPoints: Extraneous parts are metal items not belonging to the electrical installation
They are identified by their ability to bring Earth potential into a location
Resistance testing (e.g., < 22kΩ) confirms if they are liable to introduce this potential
They differ from exposed parts because they do not contain or support electrical components
expectedAnswer: We know a part is an extraneous-conductive-part if it is a metal object that is not part of the electrical system and does not house components, but is connected to the ground. This connection means it introduces Earth potential into the building. We often confirm this by measuring if the resistance to earth is low (e.g., below 22kΩ).

An extraneous-conductive-part is non-electrical metalwork that is distinct from exposed parts because it contains no wiring. It is identified by its low-resistance connection to the mass of the earth, which allows it to introduce earth potential into the installation.
questions.hint: Focus on the source of the potential and whether the part is actually part of the electrical system.

questions.questionText: An inspector identifies the following four items in a room: a metal motor housing, a plastic light switch, a copper gas pipe, and a wooden door frame. How many of these items meet the definition of a 'conductive part'?
questions.hint: Count only the items made of material capable of carrying electric current (the motor housing and the gas pipe).

questions.questionText: Explain why a metal water pipe that enters a building from the ground is classified as an extraneous-conductive-part rather than an exposed-conductive-part.
expectedAnswer: not part of the electrical installation
questions.hint: Focus on whether the item is an intended component of the electrical system itself or external to it.

questions.questionText: A metal storage rack in a warehouse is bolted directly into the building's structural steel frame, which is embedded in the ground. If this rack is liable to introduce earth potential into the location, how is it classified?
questions.hint: This is a conductive part that is not part of the electrical installation but introduces a potential (low resistance to earth).

questions.questionText: Under normal operating conditions (no faults), what is the intended voltage of an exposed-conductive-part, such as a metal appliance casing?
questions.hint: The part is not normally live. Provide the numeric value in Volts.

questions.questionText: Explain the fundamental difference between the metallic housings of electrical equipment and the structural metalwork found within a building environment. In your answer, include: (1) the definition of an exposed-conductive-part, (2) the definition of an extraneous-conductive-part, and (3) the specific relationship each has to the electrical system. Why is this distinction critical for determining the correct safety measures? (2-3 sentences)
keyPoints: Defines exposed-conductive-part as a part of electrical equipment which can be touched and is not normally live.
Defines extraneous-conductive-part as a conductive part not forming part of the electrical installation.
Identifies that exposed parts are internal to the electrical system's components.
Identifies that extraneous parts are external to the system but liable to introduce a potential (often confirmed by <22kΩ resistance).
Reasons that the distinction is necessary because each requires different protective treatments to prevent shock.
expectedAnswer: An exposed-conductive-part is a metallic housing of the electrical system that can become live during a fault, whereas an extraneous-conductive-part is external metalwork like a pipe that is not part of the system but can introduce a potential. This distinction is critical because it dictates whether a part requires earthing as part of the circuit or protective bonding to the installation's main earthing terminal. We know this because the origin of the potential—internal fault versus external introduction—determines the safety path required.

Exposed-conductive-parts are components of the electrical installation itself, such as conduit or motor casings, while extraneous-conductive-parts are external items like structural steel or gas pipes. The relationship holds because safety regulations categorize parts based on their function within or outside the electrical circuit. This distinction is vital for ensuring that the correct protective measures, such as automatic disconnection of supply or bonding, are applied to the specific type of metalwork.
questions.hint: Think about which parts are intended to hold electrical components and which parts belong to the building's infrastructure.

questions.questionText: Evaluate how various conductive components in a facility are categorized and managed to maintain a safe environment. In your answer, include: (1) the criteria for identifying parts that are part of the electrical system, (2) the criteria for parts that are external to it, (3) how these categories are distinguished during an inspection, and (4) how these classifications together ensure overall installation safety. Answer in 3-4 sentences OR concise bullet points.
keyPoints: Criteria for exposed parts: part of equipment, touchable, can become live under fault.
Criteria for extraneous parts: not part of installation, liable to introduce potential (e.g., earth potential).
Distinction method: verifying if the part encloses electrical conductors or is independent metalwork (using resistance tests if needed).
Integration: Exposed parts are earthed to facilitate rapid disconnection of supply during faults.
Integration: Extraneous parts are bonded to maintain an equipotential zone.
Technical precision: Correct use of 'potential', 'fault conditions', and 'installation' terms.
Synthesis: Combined application prevents dangerous touch voltages between different conductive surfaces.
expectedAnswer: Conductive parts are categorized by their role: exposed-conductive-parts are the metallic enclosures of the electrical system itself, while extraneous-conductive-parts are external metalwork like moisture-prone pipes. During inspection, these are distinguished by determining if the part is an integral housing for electrical components or an independent structural element. By classifying them correctly, installers can apply earthing to exposed parts for fault protection and bonding to extraneous parts to eliminate potential differences, creating a safe equipotential environment.

• Exposed-conductive-parts are identified as metallic enclosures belonging to the electrical system that may become live during a fault.
• Extraneous-conductive-parts are identified as external metallic structures liable to introduce a potential, such as water mains or steel frames.
• Inspectors distinguish them by evaluating if the component is part of the electrical equipment or part of the building's non-electrical services.
• These classifications ensure safety by allowing for specific protective measures—earthing for system parts and bonding for external parts—to prevent electric shock.
questions.hint: Consider how identifying the source of a potential (internal fault vs. external earth) determines the protective method used.

questions.questionText: What type of material, such as copper or aluminum, allows electric current to flow easily?
questions.hint: This is the opposite of an insulator.

questions.questionText: What is the unit of measurement for electrical resistance?
questions.hint: This unit is represented by the Greek letter Omega (Ω) and is key to determining if a part is conductive.

questions.questionText: What is the standard voltage potential of the general mass of the Earth?
questions.hint: Think of the voltage reference point for the entire electrical system.

scope.inScope: The definitions, characteristics, and visual identification of exposed and extraneous conductive parts, including the use of resistance values (e.g., 22kΩ) to verify extraneous parts.
scope.outOfScope: Installation methods for protective bonding conductors or calculation of earth fault loop impedance.
scope.rationale: Foundational terminology and part identification must be mastered before moving to the practical application of earthing and bonding regulations.

teachingConstraints.specificScope: Focus exclusively on the classification and identification of parts

misconceptions.misconception: All metal objects in a room are exposed conductive parts.
misconceptions.correction: Only metal parts that are actually part of the electrical equipment or system (like enclosures or conduits) are classified as exposed.

misconceptions.misconception: Any piece of metal in a building is an extraneous conductive part.
misconceptions.correction: It must be liable to introduce a potential (usually by being in contact with the ground, like a buried pipe) to be classified as extraneous. Isolated metal is not extraneous.
